questions.text: A 65 year old male living in a rural area came to the village PHC with complaints of weakness , excessive thirst and increased frequency of urination for the past 5 months. His wife said that he is also eating more. The MO immediately suspected a diagnosis. What could be the most appropriate next indicator in history?

options.label: C
options.text: Ask for presence of blood in urine

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Ask for weight loss The classical triad of Diabetes Mellitus is WEIGHT LOSS , POLYDIPSIA and POLYURIA. In a 65 y/o male with no additional history of either trauma , longstanding h/o hypertension or edema the best answer among given options will be to elicit weight loss history. Excessive thirst , polyuria and weight loss points to DM

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option B - Any associated h/o progressive vision worsening due to refractive error , cataracts or glaucoma is missing Option C - No h/o trauma to perineum or urethra given in question Option D - patient is not malingering, we can diagnose it as an organic cause.

questions.text: A patient presented to opd with a complaint of increased frequency of voiding of urine. He is otherwise asymptomatic , blood glucose and basal plasma osmolality are within normal limits. Serum sodium is 128mEQ/L. After conducting a urine osmolality test , investigations revealed urine osmolality = 240 mosm / kg, . The physician advised him to take a water deprivation test . The repeat urine osmolality came out to be 560 mosm/kg. What could be the condition, the patient is suffering from?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Primary polydipsia Primary polydipsia is a psychogenic illness , an abnormality in cognition of thirst that causes excessive intake of fluids and an increase in body water that reduces plasma osmolarity , Serum Sodium, and urinary concentration. Approach to polyuria - Patient presents with increased urine output. Upon estimation of urine osmolality Increased urine osmolality(>300 mosm/Kg) could be due to solute loss , Diabetes Mellitus or due to Mannitol infusion Decreased urine osmolality coupled with increase in urine osmolality upon water deprivation test points towards primary polydipsia(as water deprivation will directly increase urine osmolality) Nephrogenic or Central DI also shows decreased urine osmolality initially although after a water deprivation test there is no change in urine osmolality as the body is unable to concentrate urine.

Highyeild:

To differentiate between nephrogenic or central Diabetes insipidus- SERUM ADH- DECREASED IN CENTRAL DI DESMOPRESSIN TEST : URINE OSMOLALITY INCREASED IN CENTRAL DI Primary polydipsia Diabetes insipidus (2° polydipsia) ● Psychogenic polydipsia (compulsive drinker) ● Kidney cannot concentrate urine ● S.Na+- ↓ / (N) ● S.Na 1/(N) ● •Water deprivation Test: - Urine osmolality tt (>50%) ● Referred to psychiatry Urine osmolality unchanged / (if t <50%)

Nephrogenic DI - due to resistance to ADH action - will have no change in urine osmolality in water deprivation test. Option D. Diabetes will have increased plasma glucose level, which is normal here. So diabetes is very less likely.

questions.text: A 55 y/o male with history of hypertension presented to the opd with polyuria . He is on lithium therapy for bipolar disorder since 1 year. Investigations revealed normal sodium levels with slightly decreased urinary sodium along with normal serum albumin . Serum glucose is 123 mg/dl. The physician then advised an ADH stimulation test but there was no change in urine osmolality. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

lithium induced nephrogenic di Approach to the case - The Patient is a case of Hypertension with polyuria who is on concomitant Lithium therapy for bipolar disorder. Normal Serum Sodium along with slightly increased Urinary Sodium is a common presentation of early Diabetes Insipidus as there is increased fluid loss without increased solute loss . Diabetes Insipidus eventually presents with hypernatremia. To differentiate between central and nephrogenic DI , ADH stimulation test is carried out . An increase in Urine Osmolality indicates ADH deficiency and hence Central DI and no change indicates nephrogenic (receptor insensitivity) DI.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option A- the association of central diabetes insipidus (cdi) with lithium use is rare Option C- hypertensive polyuria - nocturnal polyuria was significantly associated with untreated hypertension in patients with lifestyle related diseases and overactive bladder. The association between hypertension and nocturnal polyuria was significant in women alone. Option D- siadh - siadh causes the body to retain too much water and not polyuria.

questions.text: A medical PG resident decided to do his thesis on the topic titled relationship of plasma vasopressin with urine osmolality in patients with polyuria. He saved data of 100 patients with 3 different disease profiles and made a descriptive study for which a statistical analysis was prepared with plotting of all patients in his chart as given below: Select the correct option representing green, blue and pink color patients:

options.label: A
options.text: Green = pituitary diabetes insipidus , blue = normal or primary polydipsia , pink = nephrogenic diabetes insipidus

options.label: B
options.text: Green = nephrogenic diabetes insipidus , blue = normal or primary polydipsia , pink = central diabetes insipidus

options.label: C
options.text: Green = pituitary diabetes insipidus , blue = nephrogenic diabetes insipidus , pink = normal or primary polydipsia

options.label: D
options.text: Green = pituitary diabetes insipidus , blue = normal , pink = primary polydipsia

questions.correct_answer: A. Green = pituitary diabetes insipidus , blue = normal or primary polydipsia , pink = nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Green = pituitary diabetes insipidus , blue = normal or primary polydipsia , pink = nephrogenic diabetes insipidus In Central or Pituitary Diabetes Insipidus, there is very little to no secretion of ADH , and consequently high urine osmolarity as shown in the Green Diagram. The Blue diagram represents physiological response in Osmolarity as compared to ADH secretion as an increase in Serum ADH value will lead to increase in Urine Osmolarity. The same response can be seen with primary Polydipsia as is seen with the normal physiological response. The Pink Diagram signifies High plasma Vasopressin with low Urine Osmolality as is the case in Nephrogenic DIabetes Insipidus as ADH is unable to act upon the receptors in the kidney.

questions.text: A 25 year old male presented to a clinic with polyuria (urine output > 3l/24 hrs). The patient was admitted by jr-2, who presented the case to the unit head. The unit head told the possible causes of this presentation , and explained to him the 2 basic modes of diuresis namely solute diuresis and water diuresis. Which of the following will be grouped under solute diuresis?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Mannitol Solute can cause diuresis by creating conce ntration gradients across nephron tubular membranes. For this the prerequisite is the presence of a solute of high osmotic quotient in the lumen of nephron tubules. This occurs in case of - tubular injury, diabetes , and mannitol So the answer for this question is mannitol Water diuresis means water is not being reabsorbed via the nephron tubules therefore urine becomes low in osmolality and in some cases plasma can become hyperosmolar e.g. Primary polydipsia (option a) and diabetes insipidus (option b and option c).
